data.title: Israel may have finally killed its most wanted man after seven attempts but proof of Mohammed Deif's demise may be elusive
data.meta_description: A leading Hamas military commander in Gaza has survived multiple Israeli attempts to kill him, but after a recent massive strike on what Israeli military said was a militant compound, they may have finally gotten their man — now all they need is evidence.
data.text:
The shadowy Hamas military commander in Gaza known as The Guest has dodged seven Israeli assassination attempts during decades atop its most wanted list.

Their eighth might have finally killed him after years of living underground and plotting attacks from the shadows.

Efforts to find and kill Mohammed Deif intensified following the October 7 attack, which Israel believes he orchestrated.

So when Israeli security services said they had obtained fresh intelligence that Deif was inside a humanitarian safe zone in southern Gaza late last week — a strike was ordered directly by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

A few hours later, Israel launched a massive and deadly bombardment into the Al-Mawasi area, where Palestinians had been told to flee to escape fighting, targeting what the military said was a Hamas compound.

Gazan health authorities said the strikes killed more than 90 Palestinians and injured more than 300 others.

But Israeli authorities still don't know if Deif is dead or alive.

Loading...

Who is The Guest?

His nickname was taken from his nom de guerre — Deif means guest in Arabic.

It references his habit of continually moving about to avoid detection, staying with different people only ever as a short-term guest.

As his name and slippery tactics suggest, Deif is a largely elusive and secretive figure who rarely appears in public, and there are few images of him.

The 58-year-old was one of the founders of Hamas' military wing in Gaza and has led the force for more than 20 years.

Throughout the last nine-months of fighting, he has been directing militant operations from underground and other secret locations, rarely going above ground to stay hidden, according to Israeli authorities.

Throughout the war, the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) has reportedly distributed flyers across Gaza offering rewards upwards of $US100,000 ($148,000) for information on the whereabouts of senior Hamas figures, including Deif.

But even before October 7, he had been on Israel's most wanted list for nearly three decades for his role in planning and executing several militant attacks inside Israel, including the deaths of dozens of Israelis in suicide bombings.

How Israel's most wanted man survived assassination attempts

For Deif, staying in the shadows has been a matter of life or death.

He has survived at least seven assassination attempts by Israel over the past few decades.

But he has had some close calls.

In 2002, an Israeli military helicopter fired a missile on a car he was driving in Gaza.

Deif crawled away alive but lost an eye. His arm was also permanently injured.

In 2006, Israel tried again, firing a missile at a building in Gaza where Hamas leaders had gathered.

Deif was seriously injured but escaped alive.

In another failed attempt to take Deif's life in 2014, his wife and seven-month-old son were killed in an Israeli strike on a house in Gaza.

Other family members have also been targeted.

According to the military, the last two known attempts to eliminate Deif were in 2021 when Israel and Palestinian militant groups fought an 11-day war, which Israel named Operation Guardian of the Walls.

Deif survived.

That earned him another nickname the "cat with nine lives", and helped elevate him to almost-superhero status within Palestinian militant circles.

Despite his notoriety, many people in Gaza would not recognise Deif if he walked the streets amongst them.

In rare video appearances he has only been seen as a shadow — or masked.

It's believed he has been living most of his recent years in Gaza's vast underground tunnel network, using them to constantly shift about to avoid detection.

But after months of surveillance, Israel said it had spotted Deif in a rare moment above ground.

And it was ready to act.

The operation that may have gotten The Guest

Israel hasn't revealed a lot about the latest assassination attempt on Deif publicly.

But security sources have been whispering to journalists in Israel and abroad about how the operation to target Deif unfolded.

It goes something like this, according to Hebrew media.

Israeli security forces, including the Shin Bet, had been trying to track Deif's movements for months.

They were hoping he would eventually visit another high-ranking Hamas official they have been tracking — the commander of the Khan Younis Brigades, Rafa Salama.

The New York Times has reported that Israeli security officials received a tip that Deif was in Salama's compound in the Al-Mawasi/Khan Younis area on Friday July 12.

The information was quickly relayed up through the ranks to Mr Netanyahu.

He ordered fighter jets to demolish the compound.

At 10am the next day, Israel struck.

American media reported security forces used at least five US made precision-guided bombs in the attack on and around the compound.

Gazan authorities said the strike killed more than 90 Palestinians.

An Israeli military official told the ABC security forces had carried out a "precise" and "targeted" strike after gathering intelligence that Deif and Salama had been operating from there, and that they were being guarded by several other militants.

Israel supplied before-and-after aerial photos, showing a fenced-off compound filled with trees and a few structures that were completely erased after the bombing.

Social media videos posted by Gazans on the ground showed death and destruction outside of that compound, and at least one massive crater in the ground.

Displaced people sheltering in the area said their tents had been torn down by the force of the strike, describing bodies and body parts strewn across the ground.

Israel said the bombardment killed Salama.

Deif's fate is still unknown — and it might be difficult for Israel to find out.

Why isn't Israel sure if Deif is dead?

After an initial briefing to journalists on the evening of the strike, an IDF official said there would be more updates in the following days.

Those updates haven't yet happened – likely because Israel has not been able to verify whether it has actually killed Deif.

In the aftermath of the attack, Hebrew newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth reported the Gaza hospital where the injured and dead were taken had been "put under siege by Hamas to make it difficult for IDF to identify bodies and whether one of them is Deif's".

Israeli officials have previously revealed some of the tactics they have used to monitor what's been happening on the ground in Gaza – including the use of Palestinian collaborators, and planting undercover Israeli operatives inside the strip posing as Gazans — sometimes even living there.

But the extent of damage at the site will make it hard to confirm that Deif was among those killed.

Hamas has rejected Israeli's claim that the strike was meant to target senior militant leaders.

"The occupation's claims about targeting leaders are false.This is not the first time the occupation has claimed to target Palestinian leaders, and later it is proven to be a lie," Hamas said in a statement.

"These false claims are merely a cover-up for the scale of the horrific massacre."

It would be politically and strategically advantageous for Hamas to create ambiguity around Deif's status.

After the assassination attempt, the AFP news wire reported that a senior Hamas official said Deif was "fine" and "directly supervising the operations of the military wing".

With fighting now in its ninth month in Gaza, Israel has been facing pressure over its military success there, where it promised to hunt and kill senior Hamas leaders, including Deif.

If he is dead, it will be the highest-ranking Hamas leader in Gaza to have been killed by Israel since it began its military campaign inside the Palestinian enclave.

Or he may have slipped back into the shadows.
